newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - March 31.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - March 31.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The United Pasig Against Crime, an anti-crime watchdog, says politicians are behind several kidnappings in Manila to raise funds for next year's general elections. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)
- The Philippine National Police says it will upgrade its surveillance and communications equipment to curb kidnapping. (MANILA STANDARD)
- Indonesia has been rated as the most corrupt country in Asia, but the problem is increasing in almost every country in the region, a recent survey says. (ALL PAPERS)
- The country's labour force of more than 26 million will go back to work after the long Holy Week vacation (MANILA BULLETIN)
- Eleven local and foreign companies have decided not to pursue their plans to open shop in the Philipines due to rising costs, the Board of Investments says. (BUSINESSWORLD)
- The Central Bank says it is determined to push through with its Yankee bond offering this April despite the recent increase in U.S. rates (BUSINESS DAILY)
- Singapore Telecom International wants to review the roll-out programme of its joint venture Globe Telecom, sources say (MANILA TIMES)
- The Monetary Baord has approved a petition by A Soriano Corp and the Philippine Investment Management Consultants Inc to hike their stakes in AsianBank. (ALL PAPERS)
